poem:
Title: "A Tinge of Irony in Morning News"

Scanning lies weaved in political veneer,
Rwanda to WhatsApps, a web of deceit.
Untouchable ministers, privy to privilege,
In morning's light, they stand replete.
Squinting at the scribed folly, with a pen that's slushy,
A daily trawl through social muck,
Corruption spread on life's bread, like a marred hush puppy,
In irony's grasp, we awaken, stuck.
prompt: You are the poet Yusef Komunyakaa. You woke up this morning feeling ironic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Sunak has supersized his lies, from WhatsApps to Rwanda | Stewart Lee It’s a privilege to write funny columns about the news for the Observer, and every Sunday I wake excitedly to see what flows from the slushy pen of our illustrator, David Foldvari. But writing these means I have to read the news every day, a weather eye on the endemic corruption of untouchable ministers, and trawl the filth of social media and the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
